flowRoot.flowPara: In optimization problems, we define a cost function as some kind of difference (or, in vector terms, distance) between our guess and the answer we want. In FWI, it's the difference between the forward-modeled wavefield and the recorded data. The optimal result is the set of parameters that result in the minimum difference or 'cost'. One way to find this minimum is gradient descent.

Imagine a plot of cost vs a single parameter (right) — but bear in mind that in most problems, we have a lot of parameters. We make an initial guess, then compute the derivative of the cost function (that is, the gradient g) at that point. We then add a quantity –α × g to our guess, where α is some small number; if the gradient is positive, as shown, this has the effect of increasing the parameter for the next guess. Iterating, we eventually find the minimum.
